results.title: Wentworth Correctional Centre ID Pass for Jake Stewart
results.brief_description: Wentworth’s impact on the local industry is just as important as its global popularity, providing countless opportunities for women on both sides of the camera. It also explores complex female-focused themes including institutionalised power, female transgression and violence, motherhood and LGBTQIA+ sexuality.

results.description: Prop staff pass for Jake Stewart from the set of Wentworth TV series.

results.title: Dusi and Jeno
results.brief_description:
‘Dusi and Jeno’ is compiled from footage shot by Jeno, a Budapest bank worker, between 1936 and 1966.

At the heart of this diary film is his wife Dusi, for although Jeno ventures out to capture street life, holiday vistas and public events in elegant images and thoughtfully constructed sequences, he always returns to her side; Dusi and her beloved dog in a series of tender domestic tableau. He films them at breakfast, in the garden, in the sitting room - often elegantly framed by windows and doors. We see them glimpsed in silhouette on a train journey, or placed in a beautifully composed landscape. Dusi chats to him as he films; this is the record of a twenty year conversation, much of it we gather about their ever present dog.

Even the second world war is referenced by the domestic, with Jeno returning to film the site of their bomb-destroyed home from exactly the same place he had shot it basking in sunlight years before.

Dusi’s hair turns grey over the years, three dogs take their turn at her side. After her death Jeno remarries; the rhythm of images shifts, the love poem has ended.

results.title: Class lot
results.brief_description:
Gyorgy Peto, an Hungarian businessman and musician, took a large number of home movies. Like many film hobbyists he chose to record the special days and lighter moments in life; his wife Eva on holidays, a new baby being bathed, daughter Kati at her birthday party, and his nightly job playing viola in the Budapest Metropolitan Operetta. Director Peter Forgacs takes these “private histories”, which date from 1946 through to the 1960s, and creates an evocative family portrait, layering the sequences of affectionate domestic images with footage from other sources that reveals the much harsher “official history” of a Jewish family during the Second World War and the communist era of the fifties.

Woven into the soundtrack is the voice of the adult Kati, who reminisces about her youth and her relationship with her parents. As a child of holocaust survivors, there was much that could not be spoken about. Kati remarks, “I always felt things were somewhere else, not where I was.” The more we learn about the experiences of Gyorgy, Eva and their extended family, the more the transient moments of casual happiness captured by the home movies grow in emotional power. This exploration of memory and history, presence and loss is supported by the music of Tibor Szemzo.

results.title: Film Ist
results.creator_credit: Gustav Deutsch, Manfred Neuwirth and LOOP TV-Video-Film
results.brief_description: Austrian filmmaker Gustav Deutsch is one of contemporary cinema’s pre-eminent avantgarde artists. After several years combing a massive archive of scientific films, Deutsch released ‘Film Ist (1-6)’, a film made up of found footage edited together into extraordinary assemblages of sound and image. The fragments of film traverse a vast range of human experimentation with time, light, motion, and the human form. We see vocal chords at work while we hear a singer rehearsing. As if peering into the suppressed memory of cinema itself, we see an eye being excised from the socket, the slow motion movement of apes, bullets, children and cats, and the world offered back to us as a phantasmagoria of wave forms, wind patterns, lightning flashes and electrical currents. Cinema was born out of scientific endeavour and has since redefined so much of how we understand the physical and temporal properties of the world. ‘Film Ist’ is a remarkable surrealistic report on cinema’s own memory of its mysterious role in the creation of the modern world.

results.title: The Hour before my brother dies
results.creator_credit: James Clayden, Noel Price, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Daniel Keene
results.brief_description: Adapted from the stage play by Daniel Keene. Sally visits her brother Martin, the hour before he is due to be hanged for murder. What is the hold these two have on each other physically and emotionally? Cast includes Peter Hehir (Martin), Rhonda Wilson (Sally), Reg Evans (father) and Margot Duell (mother).

results.title: Melbourne rising
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Sam De Silva and SKA TV
results.brief_description: ‘Melbourne Rising’ is a video document about the S11 protests against the World Economic Forum at Crown Casino in Melbourne. The protests aimed to shut down the summit in opposition to the injustices of corporate driven globalisation. After its release in late September 2000, Melbourne Rising was screened and broadcast in Canada, the Czech Republic, Germany, Italy, the Neteherlands, New Zealand, Switzerland, the UK and the USA. It also featured in numerous film festivals across Australia as well as Korea and India.
